section.continued: then the owner of the ship (if at fault) commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 5 and to imprisonment for 2 years and the master of the ship (if at fault) commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

subsection.leadIn: The master of every ship to which this section applies shall enter in the official log-book a statement, or, if there is no official log-book, keep some other record, of every occasion on which boat-drill or fire-drill is practised on board ship, or on which the appliances and equipment required to be carried by virtue of the life-saving appliances regulations and the fire-fighting appliances regulations are examined to see whether they are fit and ready for use and of the result of any such examination; and if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of a passenger ship, boat-drill or fire-drill is not practised on board the ship in any week;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of any other ship, boat-drill or fire-drill is not practised on board ship in any month;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in the case of any ship, the appliances and equipment are not examined in any such period as may be prescribed,

subsection.continued: the master shall enter a statement or keep some other record of the reasons why the drill was not practised or the appliances and equipment were not examined in that week, month or period.

subsection.content: The master shall, if so required by an officer of the Marine Department, produce for inspection any such entry or record.
If a master fails to comply with any requirement of this section, he commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 2. (Amended E.R. 5 of 2021)

subsection.leadIn: Subject to section 46, this section applies to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any ship registered in Hong Kong; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: other ships while they are within the waters of Hong Kong.

section.name: s46
section.heading: Application to ships not registered in Hong Kong
section.leadIn: Sections 43 and 44 shall apply to all ships not registered in Hong Kong while within the waters of Hong Kong to the same extent as they apply to ships registered in Hong Kong:

proviso.name: proviso
proviso.leadIn: Provided that such sections and section 45 shall not apply—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to any Convention ship which carries an accepted Convention certificate; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: by reason of a ship not registered in Hong Kong being within the waters of Hong Kong, to the ship if it would not have been within such waters but for stress of weather or any other circumstance that neither the master nor the owner of the ship could have prevented or forestalled.

part.name: P4
part.heading: Load Lines

subsection.leadIn: In this Part, unless the context otherwise requires—
subsection.def: alteration (改動) includes deterioration;
conditions of assignment (勘定條件) means such provisions relating to the assignment of freeboards as are contained in the load line regulations;

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: a territory to which the Convention of 1966 extends; (Replaced 10 of 2009 s. 14)

subsection.def: deck-line (甲板線) means such mark as may be prescribed which indicates on each side of a ship the position of the freeboard deck of that ship;
existing ship (現有船舶) means any ship which is not a new ship;

def.name: InternationalVoyage
def.leadIn: international voyage (國際航程) means, subject to subsection (2), a voyage between—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: a port in a Convention country and a port outside that Convention country (whether in a Convention country or not); (Replaced 10 of 2009 s. 14)

subsection.def: load lines (載重線) means such lines as may be prescribed which indicate on each side of a ship the various maximum depths to which the ship may be loaded in such circumstances as may be prescribed;

def.name: NewShip
def.leadIn: new ship (新船舶) means a ship whose keel is laid, or which is at a similar stage of construction on or after—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in relation to a ship registered in Hong Kong or which flies the flag of Hong Kong, 16 August 1972; (Replaced 10 of 2009 s. 14)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in relation to a ship whose parent country is a Convention country (other than a ship mentioned in paragraph (a)), the date from which the Convention of 1966 has come into force in respect of that Convention country or (in the case of a territory) the date from which the Convention of 1966 has been extended to that territory; and (Replaced 10 of 2009 s. 14)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in relation to any other ship, 16 August 1972; (Added 10 of 2009 s. 14)

subsection.def: parent country (母國家) means, in relation to a ship, the country or territory in which the ship is registered, or, if the ship is not registered anywhere, means the country or territory whose flag the ship flies;

def.name: ValidConventionCertificate
def.leadIn: valid Convention certificate (有效公約證明書) means a certificate which—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: has been issued under section 57(2) and is for the time being in force; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is produced in circumstances in which it is required by the load line regulations to be recognized for the purposes of this Part.

subsection.content: In determining, for the purposes of an international voyage, what are the ports between which a voyage is made, no account shall be taken of any deviation by a ship from her intended voyage which is due solely to stress of weather or any other circumstances which neither the master nor the owner of the ship could have prevented or forestalled; and for the purposes of determining whether a voyage is an international voyage any colony, protectorate or other dependency, any territory for whose international relations a government is separately responsible and any territory for which the United Nations are the administering authority, shall be taken to be a separate territory.

Any reference in this Part to the gross tonnage of a ship shall be construed as a reference to the tonnage of a ship ascertained in accordance with the tonnage regulations made under the Merchant Shipping (Registration) Ordinance (Cap. 415); and where in accordance with those regulations alternative tonnages are assigned to a ship, the gross tonnage of the ship shall, for the purposes of this Part be taken to be the larger of those tonnages. (Amended 74 of 1990 s. 104)

subsection.leadIn: Subject to any exemption conferred by or under this Ordinance, no ship registered in Hong Kong shall proceed or attempt to proceed to sea unless—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the ship has been surveyed in accordance with the load line regulations;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the ship is marked with a deck-line and with load lines in accordance with those regulations;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the ship complies with the condition of assignment; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the information required by those regulations to be provided for the guidance of the master of the ship has been so provided.

subsection.content: If any ship proceeds or attempts to proceed to sea in contravention of subsection (1), the owner or master of the ship commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 3. (Amended E.R. 5 of 2021)

Any ship which in contravention of subsection (1) attempts to proceed to sea without being surveyed and marked as mentioned in paragraphs (a) and (b) of that subsection may be detained until it has been so surveyed and marked.
Any such ship as is mentioned in subsection (1) which does not comply with the conditions of assignment shall be deemed to be unsafe for the purposes of section 67.

subsection.leadIn: A ship registered in Hong Kong shall not be so loaded that its condition at any time is such that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the ship is in salt water and has no list, the appropriate load line on each side of the ship is submerged; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in any other case, the appropriate load line on each side of the ship would be submerged if the ship were in salt water and had no list.

subsection.leadIn: If any ship is loaded in contravention of subsection (1), the owner or master of the ship, subject to subsection (5), commits an offence and is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to a fine of $10,000; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to such additional fine, not exceeding an amount calculated in accordance with subsection (3), as the court thinks fit to impose, having regard to the extent to which the earning capacity of the ship was increased by reason of the contravention.

subsection.leadIn: Any additional fine imposed under subsection (2)(b) shall not exceed $6,000 for every 25 millimetres and for any fraction of 25 millimetres over and above one or more complete multiple of 25 millimetres, by which—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in a case falling within subsection (1)(a), the appropriate load line on each side of the ship was submerged; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in a case falling within subsection (1)(b), the appropriate load line on each side of the ship would have been submerged as therein mentioned,

subsection.continued: and, if the amount by which that load line was or would have been submerged was less than 25 millimetres, any such additional fine shall be $6,000.

subsection.content: If the master of a ship takes the ship to sea when it is loaded in contravention of subsection (1), or if any other person, having reason to believe that the ship is so loaded, sends or is party to sending it to sea when it is loaded in contravention of that subsection, then (without prejudice to any fine to which he may be liable in respect of an offence under subsection (2)) he commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 4. (Amended E.R. 5 of 2021)

Where a person is charged with an offence under subsection (2), it shall be a defence to prove that the contravention was due solely to deviation or delay and that the deviation or delay was caused solely by stress of weather or other circumstances which neither the master nor the owner could have prevented or forestalled.
Without prejudice to any proceedings under the preceding provisions of this section, any ship which is loaded in contravention of subsection (1) may be detained until it ceases to be so loaded.

subsection.def: For the purposes of the application of this section to a ship in any circumstances prescribed by the load line regulations the appropriate load line (適當載重線) means the maximum depth to which the ship may, in accordance with those regulations, be loaded in salt water in those circumstances.

section.name: s50
section.heading: Miscellaneous offences in relation to marks
section.leadIn: Where a ship registered in Hong Kong is marked in accordance with any requirements as to marking imposed by or under this Part, then if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the owner or master of the ship fails without reasonable cause to keep the ship so marked; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any person conceals, removes, alters, defaces or obliterates, or causes or permits any person under his control to conceal, remove, alter, deface or obliterate, any mark with which the ship is so marked, except where he does so under the authority of a person empowered under the load line regulations to authorize him in that behalf,

section.continued: he commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 3.

section.name: s51
section.heading: Issue or endorsement of load line certificate

subsection.content: Where a ship registered in Hong Kong has been surveyed and marked in accordance with the load line regulations, an International Load Line Certificate shall be issued to the owner, agent or master of the ship on his application.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (3), any certificate required by subsection (1) of this section to be issued—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: shall be issued by the Director or by a person authorized by the Director; and (Amended 56 of 1990 s. 4)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: shall be in such form, and shall be issued in such manner, as may be prescribed by the load line regulations.

subsection.leadIn: The Director may request the government of a Convention country to cause a ship registered in Hong Kong to which this Part applies to be surveyed and to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: issue or authorize the issue of, in respect of the ship, an International Load Line Certificate; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where appropriate, endorse or authorize the endorsement of the International Load Line Certificate issued in respect of the ship in accordance with the Convention of 1966. (Replaced 10 of 2009 s. 15)

subsection.content: For the purposes of this Part, an endorsement made on the certificate by the government of a Convention country on behalf of the Director in conformity with the Convention of 1966 has the same effect as an endorsement made by the Director under this Part. (Added 10 of 2009 s. 15)

section.name: s52
section.heading: Effect of load line certificate
section.leadIn: Where a certificate, issued in pursuance of section 51 and for the time being in force, is produced in respect of the ship to which the certificate relates—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the ship shall be deemed to have been surveyed in accordance with the load line regulations; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if lines are marked on the ship corresponding in number and description to the deck-line and load lines as required by the load line regulations, and the positions of those lines so marked correspond to the positions of the deck-line and load lines as specified in the certificate, the ship shall be deemed to be marked as required by those regulations.

section.name: s53
section.heading: Endorsement of load line certificates
section.leadIn: While any certificate issued under section 51 is in force in respect of a ship, there shall be endorsed on the certificate such information relating to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: periodical inspections of the ship in accordance with the load line regulations; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any extension of the period for which the certificate was issued,

section.continued: as may be prescribed by the regulations.

section.name: s54
section.heading: Ship not to proceed to sea without load line certificate

subsection.content: Subject to any exemption conferred by or under this Part, no ship registered in Hong Kong shall proceed or attempt to proceed to sea unless an International Load Line Certificate is in force in respect of the ship. (Amended 6 of 2000 s. 14)

Before any such ship proceeds to sea, the master of the ship shall produce the certificate to the Director; and a clearance shall not be granted, and the ship may be detained, until the certificate is so produced.
If any ship proceeds or attempts to proceed to sea in contravention of this section, the master of the ship commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 3. (Amended E.R. 5 of 2021)

section.name: s55
section.heading: Availability of load line certificate and entry of particulars in official log-book

subsection.leadIn: Where a certificate is issued in respect of a ship under section 51—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the owner or master of the ship shall ensure that the certificate is kept readily available on board the ship, so long as the certificate remains in force and the ship is in use, for inspection at all reasonable times by—

subparagraph.content: when the ship is in Hong Kong, a Government surveyor; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the master of the ship, before making any other entry in any official log-book relating to the ship, shall enter in it the particulars as to the positions of the deck-line and the load lines which are specified in the certificate.

subsection.leadIn: Before any ship registered in Hong Kong leaves any dock, wharf, harbour or other place for the purpose of proceeding to sea, the master of the ship—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: shall cause a notice, in such form and containing such of those particulars as may be specified in the regulations for the purposes of this paragraph, to be posted up in some conspicuous place on board the ship,

subsection.continued: and, where such a notice has been posted up, the master of the ship shall cause it to be kept so posted up and legible until the ship arrives at some other dock, wharf, harbour or place.

subsection.content: If the owner or master of a ship fails to comply with any requirement imposed on him by this section, he commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 1. (Amended E.R. 5 of 2021)
A Government surveyor may inspect any ship registered in Hong Kong, for the purpose of seeing that the provisions of this Part have been complied with in respect of the ship.
For the purposes of any such inspection any such surveyor shall have all the powers conferred by section 115.

part.crossHeading: Ships not registered in Hong Kong

subsection.leadIn: This section applies to any ship not registered in Hong Kong, which—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is registered in a Convention country or, not being registered in any such country or elsewhere, flies the flag of a Convention country; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is either an existing ship of not less than 150 tons gross tonnage or a new ship of not less than 24 metres in length.

subsection.leadIn: The Director may, at the request of the government of the parent country of a ship to which this section applies, cause the ship to be surveyed and, if the Director is satisfied that the requirements of the Convention of 1966 are complied with, the Director may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: issue or authorize the issue of, in respect of the ship, a certificate in such form as may be prescribed by the Convention of 1966; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where appropriate, endorse or authorize the endorsement of a certificate issued in respect of the ship in accordance with the Convention of 1966. (Replaced 10 of 2009 s. 17)

subsection.content: Certificates issued as mentioned in subsection (2) shall be included among the certificates to be called “International Load Line Certificates”. (Amended 6 of 2000 s. 15)

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (2), and to any exemption conferred by or under this Ordinance, no ship not being a ship registered in Hong Kong shall proceed, or attempt to proceed, to sea from Hong Kong unless—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the ship has been surveyed in accordance with the load line regulations;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the ship is marked with a deck-line and with load lines in accordance with those regulations;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the ship complies with the conditions of assignment; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the information required by those regulations to be provided for the guidance of the master of the ship has been so provided.

subsection.content: Subsection (1) does not apply to a ship in respect of which a valid Convention certificate is produced.
If any ship proceeds or attempts to proceed to sea in contravention of subsection (1) the owner or master of the ship commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 3. (Amended E.R. 5 of 2021)

Any ship which in contravention of this section attempts to proceed to sea without being surveyed and marked as mentioned in subsection (1)(a) and (b) may be detained until it has been so surveyed and marked.

If any such ship as is mentioned in subsection (1), not being a ship in respect of which a valid Convention certificate is produced, does not comply with the conditions of assignment, section 72 has effect in relation to the ship as if it were unsafe for the purposes of that section. (Amended 23 of 1998 s. 2; 10 of 2009 s. 18)

subsection.leadIn: Where a ship not registered in Hong Kong is within the waters of Hong Kong, the ship shall not be so loaded that its condition at any time is such that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the ship is in salt water and has no list, the appropriate load line on each side of the ship is submerged; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in any other case, the appropriate load line on each side of the ship would be submerged if the ship were in salt water and had no list.

content.leadIn: Subsections (2), (3), (5) and (6) of section 49 shall have effect for the purposes of this section as if any references in those subsections to subsection (1) of that section, or to paragraph (a) or paragraph (b) of the said subsection (1), were a reference to subsection (1), or (as the case may be) to the corresponding paragraph of subsection (1), of this section:
content.proviso: Provided that, in the case of a ship to which section 57 applies, the ship shall not be detained, and no proceedings shall be brought by virtue of this subsection, unless the ship has been inspected by a Government surveyor in pursuance of section 61.

subsection.def: In relation to a ship in respect of which a valid Convention certificate is produced, load line (載重線) in subsection (1) means a line marked on the ship in the position of a load line specified in that certificate; and for the purposes of the application of the relevant provisions to such a ship in any circumstances for which a particular load line is specified in the certificate, the appropriate load line (適當載重線) means the maximum depth to which the ship may, in accordance with the certificate, be loaded in salt water in those circumstances.

Where a valid Convention certificate is not produced in respect of a ship, then, for the purposes of the application of the relevant provisions to that ship in any circumstances prescribed by the load line regulations the appropriate load line (適當載重線) means the maximum depth to which the ship may, in accordance with those regulations, be loaded in salt water in those circumstances.
In subsections (3) and (4) the relevant provisions (有關條文) means the provisions of subsection (1) and any provisions of section 49 as applied by subsection (2).

section.name: s60
section.heading: Production of certificate to Director
section.content: Subject to any exemption conferred by or under this Part, before a ship to which section 57 applies proceeds to sea from Hong Kong on an international voyage, the master of the ship shall produce a valid Convention certificate to the Director; and a clearance shall not be granted, and the ship may be detained, until such a certificate is so produced.

subsection.content: Subject to this section, a Government surveyor may inspect any ship not registered in Hong Kong while the ship is within the waters of Hong Kong and for the purposes of any such inspection he shall have all the powers conferred by section 115.

Any such Government surveyor may go on board any ship to which section 57 applies, while the ship is within the waters of Hong Kong, for the purpose of demanding production of any International Load Line Certificate for the time being in force in respect of the ship. (Amended 6 of 2000 s. 16)

subsection.leadIn: If on any such demand a valid Convention certificate is produced to the surveyor in respect of the ship, the powers of the surveyor under subsection (1) shall be limited to seeing that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the ship is not loaded beyond the limits allowed by the certificate;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: lines are marked on the ship in the positions of the load lines specified in the certificate;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: no material alterations have taken place in the hull or superstructures of the ship which affect the position in which any of those lines ought to be marked; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the fittings and appliances for the protection of openings, the guard rails, the freeing ports and the means of access to the crew’s quarters have been maintained on the ship in as effective a condition as they were in when the certificate was issued.

subsection.content: If on an inspection of a ship under this section the ship is found to have been so materially altered in respect of the matters referred to in paragraph (c) or paragraph (d) of subsection (3) that the ship is manifestly unfit to proceed to sea without danger to human life, section 72 has effect in relation to the ship as if it were unsafe for the purposes of that section. (Amended 23 of 1998 s. 2; 10 of 2009 s. 19)

Where a ship is detained under the provisions applied under subsection (4), the Director shall order the ship to be released as soon as he is satisfied that the ship is fit to proceed to sea without danger to human life.

The Director may exempt any ship or class of ships from this Part or the load line regulations if he is satisfied that the sheltered nature and conditions of voyages undertaken by such ships make it unreasonable or impracticable to apply this Part or the load line regulations.

The Director may exempt any ship which embodies features of a novel kind from any of the provisions of this Part or the load line regulations the application of which may seriously impede research into the development of such features and their incorporation in ships engaged on international voyages.

The Director may, in relation to a ship which does not normally ply on international voyages but is, in exceptional circumstances, required to undertake a single international voyage, exempt the ship from this Part and the load line regulations while the ship is engaged on that voyage; but no exemption shall be conferred unless the Director is satisfied that the ship complies with such safety requirements as are, in his opinion, adequate for the voyage which is to be undertaken by the ship.

Any exemption conferred under this section may be conferred subject to such conditions as the Director thinks fit; and where any such exemption is conferred subject to conditions, the exemption shall not have effect unless those conditions are complied with.
Where the Director exempts a ship under section 62 he shall issue an International Load Line Exemption Certificate to the owner or master of the ship.
Any certificate issued under this section shall be in such form, and shall be issued in such manner, as may be prescribed by the load line regulations.

section.name: s64
section.heading: Endorsement of exemption certificates
section.leadIn: While any certificate issued under section 63 is in force in respect of a ship, there shall be endorsed on the certificate such information relating to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: periodical inspections of the ship in accordance with the load line regulations; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any extension of the period for which the certificate was issued,

section.continued: as may be prescribed by the regulations.

subsection.content: Where in pursuance of the passenger ship construction regulations a passenger ship registered in Hong Kong is marked with subdivision load lines, and the lowest of those lines is lower than the line which, apart from this subsection, would be the appropriate load line for the purposes of section 49, that section shall have effect as if that subdivision load line were the appropriate load line for the purposes of that section.

Where in pursuance of the passenger ship construction regulations, or in pursuance of the Convention or any law of any country made for the purpose of giving effect to the Convention, a passenger ship, not being a ship registered in Hong Kong, is marked with subdivision load lines, and the lowest of those load lines is lower than the line which, apart from this subsection, would be the appropriate load line for the purposes of section 59, that section shall have effect as if that subdivision load line were the appropriate load line for the purposes of that section.
Section 28 and section 32 shall have effect in relation to any certificate which can be issued under this Part as they have effect in relation to a certificate under Part II.
Any certificate issued under this Part shall be admissible in evidence.

section.name: s67
section.heading: Offence in respect of dangerously unsafe ship

subsection.leadIn: If—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a ship in Hong Kong; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a ship registered in Hong Kong which is in any other port,

subsection.continued: is, having regard to the nature of the service for which the ship is intended, unfit by reason of the condition of the ship’s hull, equipment or machinery or by reason of undermanning or by reason of overloading or improper loading to go to sea without serious danger to human life, then, subject to subsection (2), the master and the owner shall each commit an offence and be liable to a fine of $500,000 and to imprisonment for 2 years.

subsection.leadIn: It shall be a defence in proceedings for an offence under subsection (1) to prove that at the time of the alleged offence—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: arrangements had been made which were appropriate to ensure that before the ship went to sea it was made fit to do so without serious danger to human life by reason of the matters set out in subsection (1) which are specified in the charge; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: it was reasonable not to have made such arrangements.

subsection.content: A prosecution under this section may only be commenced by or with the consent of the Secretary for Justice. (Amended L.N. 362 of 1997)

section.name: s68
section.heading: Power to detain unsafe ships, and procedure for detention

subsection.content: Any ship registered in Hong Kong and for the time being in the waters of Hong Kong which is unsafe within the meaning of section 67(1) may be detained in accordance with this section. (Amended 74 of 1990 s. 104; 10 of 2009 s. 21)
If the Director has reason to believe that a ship is unsafe, he may appoint a surveyor to survey the ship and report to him.
If, on receipt of a report under subsection (2), the Director is of the opinion that the ship to which the report relates is unsafe, he may order that the ship be detained.

subsection.leadIn: Where an order for the detention of a ship is made under subsection (3)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Director shall serve on the owner, agent or master of the ship a copy of the report submitted to him under subsection (2);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: within 7 days after the service of the survey report under paragraph (a), the owner, agent or master of the ship may—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: apply to the Director to order that the ship be re-surveyed in accordance with subsection (5); or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: appeal against the detention order to a court of survey.

subsection.leadIn: Where the Director orders that a ship be re-surveyed following an application under subsection (4)(b), the ship shall be re-surveyed by the surveyor who made the survey under subsection (2) and shall, if so required by the owner, agent or master of the ship, be accompanied when carrying out the re-survey by an assessor, being a person of nautical, engineering or other special skill—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: nominated by the owner, agent or master of the ship; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: approved by the Director.

subsection.leadIn: On completion of the re-survey of a ship under subsection (5)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the surveyor and the assessor are in agreement, the Director shall, on receipt of the surveyor’s report, order that the ship be released or continued to be detained; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the surveyor and the assessor are not in agreement, the ship shall continue to be detained and the owner, agent or master shall have the same right of appeal to a court of survey against the re-survey report as is provided in subsection (4)(b)(ii).

subsection.content: Where, following the making of an order for the detention of a ship under subsection (3), the owner, agent or master carries out work to make the ship fit to proceed to sea, the owner, agent or master may apply to the Director to have the ship re-surveyed; and if, on a re-survey, the Director is satisfied that the ship is fit to proceed to sea he shall, subject to subsection (8), order it to be released.
The Director shall not order a ship to be released under subsection (7) until all the costs of and incidental to detention and survey and re-survey have been paid.

subsection.leadIn: Where a ship has been detained under this section, the Director may, at any time—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: refer the matter to a court of survey; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: order the ship to be released upon such conditions as he may specify.

subsection.leadIn: If a court of survey is satisfied that a ship detained under section 68 was not unsafe at the time of detention the Government shall be liable to pay to the owner of the ship— (Amended 10 of 2009 s. 22)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: his costs of and incidental to the detention and survey of the ship; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: compensation for any loss or damage sustained by him by reason of such detention and survey.

subsection.content: If a court of survey is satisfied that a ship detained under section 68 was unsafe at the time of detention the owner, agent or master of the ship shall be liable to pay to the Government the costs of and incidental to such survey and detention. (Amended 10 of 2009 s. 22)

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of this section the costs of and incidental to the detention and survey of a ship shall include—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: a reasonable amount in respect of remuneration of—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the surveyor appointed under section 68(2); and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the assessor (if any) approved under section 68(5); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the costs of proceedings before a court of survey, to be determined, in case of any dispute, by the Registrar of the High Court. (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

section.name: s70
section.heading: Power to require security for costs from complainant
section.leadIn: Where a complaint is made to the Director that a ship for the time being in Hong Kong is unsafe within the meaning of section 67 he may require the complainant to give such security as the Director may determine for such costs and compensation as the Government may become liable to pay in respect of the detention and survey of the ship: (Amended 10 of 2009 s. 23)

proviso.name: proviso
proviso.leadIn: Provided that where the complaint is made by one-fourth, not being less than 3, of the seamen belonging to the ship and is not, in the opinion of the Director, frivolous or vexations—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: such security shall not be required to be given; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Director shall cause the complaint to be investigated to determine whether he should make an order for the detention of the ship under section 68. (Amended L.N. 386 of 1993)

section.name: s71
section.heading: General provisions in respect of detention order

subsection.content: A copy of any order for the detention of a ship made under section 68 and a copy of any order varying or adding to such order shall be served by the Director as soon as possible on the owner, agent or master of the ship.
For the purposes of any survey of a ship ordered under section 68, any person authorized to make the survey shall have all the powers conferred by section 115.

section.name: s72
section.heading: Application of detention provisions to ships not registered in Hong Kong

subsection.content: When a ship not registered in Hong Kong is for the time being in the waters of Hong Kong and is found to be unsafe within the meaning of section 67, the provisions of this Part relating to the detention of ships shall, subject to the modifications contained in this section, apply to that ship as if it were a ship registered in Hong Kong. (Amended 23 of 1998 s. 2)

A copy of the order for the detention of the ship shall be served forthwith on the consular officer (if any) in Hong Kong representing the country to which the ship belongs, or if there is no such consular officer, on the owner, agent or master of the ship.

Where a ship has been detained, the consular officer on the request of the owner, agent or master of the ship and, if there is no consular officer, the owner, agent or master of the ship, may require that the person, if any, appointed by the Director to survey the ship shall be accompanied by such person as such officer, or owner, agent or master, as the case may be, may nominate; and, in such case, if the surveyor and such person agree the Director shall order that the ship be released or continues to be detained, but if they differ, the ship shall continue to be detained and the owner, agent or master shall have the same right of appeal to a court of survey against the report of the surveyor as is provided in section 68(4)(b)(ii).

Where the owner, agent or master of the ship appeals to the court of survey, the consular officer on the request of such owner, agent or master, or, if there is no such consular officer, the owner, agent or master may nominate not more than 2 competent persons to be members of the court of survey.

Notwithstanding that this section is expressed to apply to any ship not registered in Hong Kong while it is for the time being within the waters of Hong Kong, this section shall not apply to a ship that would not be within such waters but for stress of weather or any other circumstance that neither the master nor the owner of the ship could have prevented or forestalled. (Amended 23 of 1998 s. 2)

section.name: s73
section.heading: Owners’ obligation to secure safety of ships

subsection.leadIn: In every contract of service, express or implied, between the owner of a ship registered in Hong Kong and the master or any seaman thereof, there shall be implied, notwithstanding any agreement to the contrary, an obligation on the owner of the ship that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the owner of the ship;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the master of the ship; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: every agent of the owner of the ship charged with—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the loading of the ship;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the preparing of the ship for sea; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: the sending of the ship to sea,

subsection.continued: shall use all reasonable means to ensure the safety of the ship for the voyage at the time when the voyage commences and to keep it in a safe condition during the voyage.

subsection.content: Nothing in this section shall subject the owner of a ship to any liability by reason of the ship being sent to sea in an unseaworthy state where, owing to special circumstances, the sending of the ship to sea in such a state was reasonable and justifiable.
The Chief Executive may, whenever the occasion may arise, appoint by warrant under his hand and the seal of Hong Kong a court of survey.

subsection.leadIn: A court of survey shall consist of not less than 3 nor more than 5 members, of whom—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: one shall be a judge, district judge or magistrate, who shall preside over the court; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the remainder shall be master mariners or persons of nautical, engineering or other special skill or knowledge.

section.name: s75
section.heading: Procedure in respect of courts of survey

subsection.content: All proceedings before a court of survey shall be heard in open court.
Every member of the court may survey the ship subject of the proceedings and, for that purpose, shall have all of the powers conferred by section 115.
The court may order a ship to be surveyed and, for that purpose, may appoint, by majority vote in case of disagreement, any competent person to survey the ship and report thereon to the court.

content.leadIn: The court shall have the same powers as are vested in the Director under this Ordinance to order that a ship be released or detained:
content.proviso: Provided that unless a majority of the members of the court concur in an order for the detention of the ship the court shall order that the ship be released.

subsection.content: The owner, agent and master of any ship subject of the proceedings and any person appointed by the owner, agent or master of the ship may attend at any inspection or survey of a ship made or ordered by the court.

subsection.leadIn: The court may make such order with respect to the cost of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any proceedings before the court; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any inspection or survey of a ship made or ordered by the court,

subsection.continued: which costs shall be recoverable as a civil debt.

subsection.content: The presiding officer of the court shall send to the Chief Executive such report as may be directed by regulations made under section 109 and each other member of the court shall either sign the report or report to the Chief Executive the reasons for his dissent. (Amended 10 of 2009 s. 26)

section.name: s76
section.heading: Nothing to affect admiralty jurisdiction of High Court
section.text: Nothing in this Part shall either affect, or be deemed to affect, the admiralty jurisdiction of the High Court.

subsection.leadIn: The owner, master and any person for the time being responsible for the conduct of a ship registered in Hong Kong— (Amended 56 of 1990 s. 5)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: shall comply with the collision regulations; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: shall not—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: carry or exhibit any other lights; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: use any other sound-signals,

paragraph.continued: other than such as are required by those regulations.

subsection.content: If any of the collision regulations is contravened by a ship, the owner of the ship, the master and any person for the time being responsible for the conduct of the ship shall each be guilty of an offence and liable to a fine at level 4. (Replaced 56 of 1990 s. 5. Amended E.R. 5 of 2021)

It shall be a defence to a charge under subsection (2) for the person charged to prove that he took all reasonable precautions to prevent the contravention to which the charge relates. (Replaced 56 of 1990 s. 5)
The Director shall furnish a copy of the collision regulations to any master or owner of a ship who applies for it upon payment of the prescribed fee.

subsection.def: In this section ship (船、船舶) includes a junk and a trawler to which Part XII of the Merchant Shipping Ordinance (Cap. 281) applies. (Added 56 of 1990 s. 5)

section.name: s78
section.heading: Assistance to be rendered in the event of collisions

subsection.leadIn: Where two ships collide and either of those ships is registered in Hong Kong it shall be the duty of the master or person in charge of the ship registered in Hong Kong involved in the collision, if and so far as he can do so without danger to his own ship, crew and passengers (if any)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to render to the other ship, the master, crew and passengers (if any) such assistance as may be practicable and may be necessary to save them from any danger caused by the collision, and to stay by the other ship until he has ascertained that there is no need of further assistance; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: to give to the master or person in charge of the other ship—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the name of his own ship;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the name of the port to which it belongs; and

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: the names of the ports from which it comes and to which it is bound.

subsection.leadIn: If the master or person in charge of any ship involved in a collision fails without reasonable cause to comply with subsection (1)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: he commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 5; and (Amended E.R. 5 of 2021)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if he is a certificated officer, an inquiry into his conduct may be held.

section.name: s79
section.heading: Collision to be entered in official log-book

subsection.content: The master of any ship registered in Hong Kong involved in a collision shall, where it is practicable to do so, immediately after the occurrence of the collision, cause a statement thereof and the circumstances under which it occurred to be entered in the official log-book (if any) of the ship.
The entry referred to in subsection (1) shall be signed by the master and also by the mate or one of the crew.
If the master of a ship involved in a collision contravenes subsection (1) he commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 1. (Amended E.R. 5 of 2021)

section.name: s80
section.heading: Report to Director of accidents to ships

subsection.leadIn: Where any of the following casualties has occurred—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the loss or presumed loss, stranding, grounding, abandonment of or damage to a ship;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a loss of life or serious personal injury caused by fire on board or by any accident to a ship or a ship’s boat, or by any accident occurring on board a ship or ship’s boat; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any damage caused by a ship,

subsection.continued: and, at the time it occurred, the ship was registered in Hong Kong, the owner or master of the ship shall, as soon as practicable, and in any case not later than 24 hours after the ship’s arrival at the next port, submit to the Director a written report of the accident or damage.

subsection.leadIn: The report referred to in subsection (1) shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: give a brief description of the accident or damage;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: state the time and place where it occurred;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: state the name of the ship and its official number, its position at the time of the report and the next port of call; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: give the particulars of any other ship involved in the accident.

subsection.content: If the owner or master of a ship fails without reasonable excuse to comply with this section he commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 3. (Amended E.R. 5 of 2021)

section.name: s81
section.heading: Notice of loss of ship registered in Hong Kong to be given to the Director

subsection.content: If the owner or agent of any ship registered in Hong Kong has reason, owing to the non-appearance of the ship or to any other circumstance, to believe that the ship has been wholly lost he shall, as soon as practicable, submit a written report of the loss to the Director.

subsection.leadIn: The written report referred to in subsection (1) shall specify—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the probable cause of the loss of the ship; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the name of the ship and its official number.

subsection.content: Any owner or agent who fails to comply with this section commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 1. (Amended E.R. 5 of 2021)

subsection.leadIn: Every person in charge of a wireless telegraph station which is under the control of the Authority under the Telecommunications Ordinance (Cap. 106), or which is established or installed under a licence issued by the Authority, shall, on receiving the signal prescribed by regulations made under section 100, regarding warnings of navigational dangers, for indicating that a message is about to be sent under those regulations— (Amended 56 of 1990 s. 6; 38 of 1993 s. 10; 36 of 2000 s. 28)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: refrain from sending messages for a time sufficient to allow other stations to receive the message; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if so required by the Director transmit the message in such manner as may be required by the Director.

subsection.content: Compliance with subsection (3) shall be deemed to be a condition of every licence issued by the Authority under the Telecommunications Ordinance (Cap. 106) in respect of the establishment or installation of a wireless telegraph station. (Amended 38 of 1993 s. 10; 36 of 2000 s. 28)

subsection.leadIn: If the master of a ship uses or displays or causes or permits any person under his authority to use or display—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any signal prescribed by regulations made under section 100 except in the circumstances and for the purposes prescribed by regulations made under that section; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any private signal, whether registered or not, which is liable to be mistaken for any signal prescribed by those regulations,

subsection.continued: he commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 4 and shall further be liable to pay compensation for any labour undertaken, risk incurred or loss sustained in consequence of the signal having been supposed to be a signal of distress; and that compensation may, without prejudice to any other remedy, be recovered in the same manner as salvage. (Amended 56 of 1990 s. 7; E.R. 5 of 2021)

subsection.content: Nothing in section 82(3) shall interfere with the transmission of signals prescribed by regulations made under section 100.

subsection.def: In this section ship (船、船舶) includes a junk and a trawler to which Part XII of the Merchant Shipping Ordinance (Cap. 281) applies. (Added 56 of 1990 s. 7)

section.name: s84
section.heading: Obligation to assist vessels, etc. in distress

subsection.content: The master of a ship registered in Hong Kong, on receiving at sea a signal of distress or information from any source that a vessel or aircraft is in distress, shall proceed with all speed to the assistance of the persons in distress (informing them if possible that he is doing so) unless he is unable, or in the special circumstances of the case considers it unreasonable or unnecessary, to do so, or unless he is released under subsection (3) or (4).

Where the master of any ship in distress has requisitioned any ship registered in Hong Kong that has answered his call, it shall be the duty of the master of the requisitioned ship to comply with the requisition by continuing to proceed with all speed to the assistance of the persons in distress.

A master shall be released from the obligation imposed by subsection (1) as soon as he is informed of the requisition of one or more ships other than his own and that the requisition is being complied with by the ship or ships requisitioned.

A master shall be released from the obligation imposed by subsection (1) and, if his ship has been requisitioned, from the obligation imposed by subsection (2), if he is informed by the persons in distress, or by the master of any ship that has reached the persons in distress, that assistance is no longer required.
If a master fails to comply with subsection (1) or subsection (2), he commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 3. (Amended E.R. 5 of 2021)

If the master of a ship registered in Hong Kong, on receiving at sea a signal of distress or information from any source that a vessel or aircraft is in distress, is unable, or in the special circumstances of the case considers it unreasonable or unnecessary, to go to the assistance of the persons in distress, he shall forthwith cause a statement to be entered in the official log-book, or if there is no official log-book cause other record to be kept, of his reasons for not going to the assistance of those persons.

The master of every ship registered in Hong Kong for which an official log-book is required shall enter, or cause to be entered, in the official log-book every signal of distress or message that a vessel, aircraft or person is in distress at sea.
Any master who fails to comply with subsection (6) or (7) commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 1. (Amended E.R. 5 of 2021)

The master of a ship registered in Hong Kong, when ice is reported on or near his course, shall at night either proceed at a safe speed or change his course so as to keep amply clear of the ice reported and of the area of danger.
The master of any ship who contravenes subsection (1) commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 3. (Amended E.R. 5 of 2021)

subsection.leadIn: No person on any ship registered in Hong Kong shall, when the ship is going ahead—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: give a helm or steering order containing the word “starboard” or “right” or any equivalent of “starboard” or “right” unless he intends that the head of the ship shall move to the right; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: give a helm or steering order containing the word “port” or “left” or any equivalent of “port” or “left” unless he intends that the head of the ship shall move to the left.

subsection.content: Any person who contravenes subsection (1) commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 1. (Amended E.R. 5 of 2021)

section.name: s87
section.heading: Offences in respect of dangerous goods

subsection.leadIn: Any person who sends by, or, not being the owner or master of the vessel, carries in, any ship any dangerous goods without—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: marking distinctly their nature on the outside of the container or package containing them; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: giving written notice of

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the nature of such goods; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the name and address of the sender or carrier thereof,

paragraph.continued: to the owner or master of the ship at or before the time of sending them to be shipped or taking the same on board the ship,

subsection.continued: commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 4:

proviso.name: proviso
proviso.leadIn: Provided that if any such person satisfies the magistrate or court that he—

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: was an agent in the shipment of the goods; and

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: was not aware of, and had no reason to suspect, that the goods shipped by him were dangerous goods,

subsection.continued: he is liable to a fine at level 2.

subsection.leadIn: Any person who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: knowingly sends by, or carries in, any ship any dangerous goods under a false description; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: falsely describes the sender or carrier of any dangerous goods,

subsection.continued: commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 5.

section.name: s88
section.heading: Stowage of dangerous goods
section.content: The owner or master of any ship may refuse to take on board any package or container which he suspects to contain dangerous goods and may require it to be opened to ascertain its contents.

subsection.leadIn: Where any dangerous goods—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: have been sent or carried, or attempted to be sent or carried, on board any ship without—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: being marked in accordance with section 87(1)(a); or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: a notice having been given in accordance with section 87(1)(b);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: have been sent or carried, or attempted to be sent or carried—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: under a false description; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: with the name of the sender or carrier falsely declared,

subsection.continued: a magistrate or court may order that the dangerous goods be forfeited to the Government and thereafter disposed of in such manner as he thinks fit. (Amended 10 of 2009 s. 28)

subsection.leadIn: A magistrate or court may make an order under subsection (1) notwithstanding that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the owner of the dangerous goods—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: may not have committed an offence under section 87 in respect of the dangerous goods; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: may not be before the magistrate or court and may not have notice of the proceedings; or

content.leadIn: there may be no evidence before the magistrate or court in respect of the ownership of the dangerous goods:
content.proviso: Provided that the magistrate or court may require notice of such proceedings to be given to the owner or shipper of the dangerous goods before making an order for their forfeiture and disposal.

section.name: s90
section.heading: Director may refuse clearance
section.content: The Director may refuse a port clearance to any passenger ship if there are on board any dangerous goods which are not stowed to his satisfaction.

section.name: s91
section.heading: Power to deal with goods suspected of being dangerous
section.content: When any dangerous goods, or any goods which in the opinion of the master or owner of the ship are dangerous goods, have been sent or brought aboard any ship without being marked in accordance with section 87(1)(a) or without any notice under section 87(1)(b) having been given, the master or owner may, having regard to all the circumstances, including the risk to persons and property on board the ship and the need to protect the marine environment, dispose of those goods together with any package or receptacle in which they are contained in such manner as he thinks fit; and neither the master nor the owner of the ship shall be subject to any liability, civil or criminal, for so disposing of the goods.

section.name: s92
section.heading: Saving for other enactments relating to dangerous goods
section.content: The provisions of this Part relating to the carriage of dangerous goods shall be in addition to and not in substitution for, or in restraint of, any other enactment relating to the carriage of dangerous goods.

subsection.content: The Secretary may make regulations for the prevention of collisions at sea. (Amended 20 of 1996 s. 9; L.N. 106 of 2002; L.N. 130 of 2007; 10 of 2009 s. 38)

subsection.leadIn: The collision regulations may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: regulate—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the lights and shapes to be carried and exhibited;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the sound signals to be carried and used; and

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: the steering and sailing rules to be observed,

paragraph.continued: by all ships registered in Hong Kong, wherever they may be; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: provide for the prevention of collisions at sea—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: between seaplanes on the surface of the water; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: between ships and seaplanes on the surface of the water.

subsection.def: In this section ship (船、船舶) includes a junk and a trawler to which Part XII of the Merchant Shipping Ordinance (Cap. 281) applies. (Added 56 of 1990 s. 8)

subsection.content: The Secretary may make regulations prescribing the requirements with which the hull, equipment and machinery of and fuel used in passenger ships registered in Hong Kong shall comply. (Amended 20 of 1996 s. 9; L.N. 106 of 2002; L.N. 130 of 2007; 10 of 2009 s. 38)

subsection.leadIn: Without prejudice to the generality of the powers conferred on the Secretary under subsection (1), the passenger ship construction regulations— (Amended L.N. 106 of 2002; L.N. 130 of 2007; 10 of 2009 s. 38)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: may require the provision in such ships—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: of plans exhibited as provided by or under the regulations, and of other information, relating to the boundaries of watertight compartments, the openings therein, the means of closing such openings and the arrangements for correcting any list due to flooding; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: of information necessary for the guidance of the master in maintaining sufficient stability to enable the ship to withstand damage; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: shall include such requirements as appear to the Secretary to be necessary to implement the provisions of the Convention prescribing the requirements which the hull, equipment and machinery of passenger ships shall comply with, except so far as those provisions are implemented by any other regulations made under this Ordinance. (Amended 20 of 1996 s. 9; L.N. 106 of 2002; L.N. 130 of 2007; 10 of 2009 s. 38)

subsection.content: This section shall not operate to prejudice the generality of any power under any other enactment to prescribe the requirements with which passenger ships shall comply. (Replaced 20 of 1996 s. 2)

If the passenger ship construction regulations are contravened in any respect in relation to a ship the owner or master of the ship commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 3. (Amended E.R. 5 of 2021)

section.name: s95
section.heading: Regulations in respect of openings in passenger ships’ hulls and watertight bulkheads

subsection.leadIn: The Secretary may make regulations in respect of passenger ships registered in Hong Kong for all or any of the following matters— (Amended 20 of 1996 s. 9; L.N. 106 of 2002; L.N. 130 of 2007; 10 of 2009 s. 38)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for closing and keeping closed the openings in hulls and watertight bulkheads;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for securing, keeping in place and inspecting contrivances for closing such openings;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: for operating the mechanisms or contrivances for closing any such openings and for drills in connexion with the operation thereof; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: for requiring entry to be made in the official log-book or other record of passenger ships of any of such matters.

subsection.content: If any regulation made under this section is contravened by any person the master of the passenger ship involved in the contravention commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 3. (Amended E.R. 5 of 2021)

section.name: s96
section.heading: Cargo ship construction and survey regulations

subsection.content: The Secretary may make regulations prescribing the requirements for the hull, equipment and machinery of and the fuel used in ships to which section 11 applies and requiring any such ships which are registered in Hong Kong to be surveyed to such extent, in such manner and at such intervals as may be prescribed by the regulations.

The cargo ship construction and survey regulations shall include such requirements as appear to the Secretary to be necessary to implement the provisions of the Convention relating to the hull, equipment and machinery of such ships, except as far as those provisions are implemented by any other regulations made under this Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: The cargo ship construction and survey regulations may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: provide that—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the contravention of any provision thereof shall be an offence; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the owner, master or such other person as the regulations shall specify shall be guilty of the offence; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: prescribe for such offence a penalty of a fine not exceeding level 4 or imprisonment for 2 years or both such fine and such imprisonment. (Replaced 56 of 1990 s. 9. Amended E.R. 5 of 2021)

subsection.content: The Secretary may make regulations requiring ships to which this section applies to be provided with radio equipment of such a nature (but not including shipborne navigational equipment) as may be prescribed by the regulations and to maintain such a radio service and to carry such number of radio officers or operators, of such grades and possessing such qualifications, as may be so prescribed; and the regulations may contain provisions for preventing, so far as practicable, electrical interference by other apparatus on board with the equipment provided under the regulations. (Amended 20 of 1996 s. 9; 6 of 2000 s. 17; L.N. 106 of 2002; L.N. 130 of 2007; 10 of 2009 s. 38)

Regulations made under this section shall include such requirements as appear to the Secretary to implement such provisions of the Convention as relate to radio installations. (Amended 20 of 1996 s. 9; 6 of 2000 s. 17; L.N. 106 of 2002; L.N. 130 of 2007; 10 of 2009 s. 38)

subsection.leadIn: Without prejudice to the generality of this section, radio regulations may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: prescribe the duties of radio officers and operators, including the duty of keeping a radio log-book;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: apply to any radio log-book required to be kept under the regulations any of the provisions of any regulations with respect to official log-books made under the Merchant Shipping (Seafarers) Ordinance (Cap. 478); (Amended 44 of 1995 s. 143)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: prescribe requirements for such portable radio apparatus as boats or life rafts may be required to carry by the life-saving appliances regulations.

subsection.content: If any radio officer or operator contravenes any regulations made in pursuance of subsection (3)(a), he commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 1 and if the radio regulations are contravened in any other respect in relation to any ship, the owner or master of the ship commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 2. (Amended E.R. 5 of 2021)

subsection.leadIn: This section applies to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: ships registered in Hong Kong; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: other ships while they are within the waters of Hong Kong.

subsection.leadIn: The Secretary may make regulations— (Amended 20 of 1996 s. 9; L.N. 106 of 2002; L.N. 130 of 2007; 10 of 2009 s. 38)

paragraph.name: a
b
c
paragraph.content: prescribing requirements which apparatus designed for the purpose of transmitting or reflecting signals to or from navigational equipment is to comply with if it is apparatus in Hong Kong or apparatus off the shores of Hong Kong but maintained from Hong Kong,

subsection.continued: and the requirements prescribed under paragraph (a) or (b) may include requirements relating to the position and method of fitting the navigational equipment.

subsection.content: If a ship to which this section applies proceeds, or attempts to proceed, to sea without carrying such navigational equipment as it is required to carry by regulations made under subsection (1) or carrying navigational equipment not complying with such regulations, the owner or master of the ship commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 3. (Amended E.R. 5 of 2021)

If any person establishes or operates any such apparatus as is mentioned in subsection (1)(c) and the apparatus does not comply with regulations made thereunder, he commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 3. (Amended E.R. 5 of 2021)

subsection.leadIn: This section applies to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: ships registered in Hong Kong; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: other ships while they are within the waters of Hong Kong.

section.name: s99
section.heading: Regulations for life-saving and fire-fighting appliances

subsection.leadIn: The Secretary may make regulations with respect to all or any of the following matters— (Amended 20 of 1996 s. 9; L.N. 106 of 2002; L.N. 130 of 2007; 10 of 2009 s. 38)

paragraph.name: a
b
c
paragraph.content: the provision in ships of a proper supply of lights and smoke signals, inextinguishable in water and fitted for attachment to lifebuoys;

paragraph.name: d
e
paragraph.content: the position and means of securing the boats, life rafts, life-jackets, lifebuoys and buoyant apparatus;

paragraph.name: f
g
paragraph.content: the manning of the lifeboats and the qualifications and certificates of lifeboatmen;

paragraph.name: h
i
paragraph.content: the provision of suitable means situated outside the engine-room whereby any discharge of water into the boats can be prevented;

paragraph.name: j
paragraph.content: the assignment of specific duties to each member of the crew in the event of emergency;

paragraph.name: k
paragraph.content: the methods to be adopted and the appliances to be carried in ships for the prevention, detection and extinction of fire;

paragraph.name: l
m
paragraph.content: the practice in ships of boat-drills and fire-drills;

paragraph.name: n
paragraph.content: the provision in ships of means of making effective distress-signals by day and by night;

paragraph.name: o
paragraph.content: the provision, in ships on voyages in which pilots are likely to be embarked, of suitable mechanical hoists, pilot-ladders, and of ropes, lights and other appliances designed to make the use of such hoists and ladders safe; and

paragraph.name: p
paragraph.content: the examination and maintenance at intervals to be prescribed by the regulations of any appliances or equipment required by the regulations to be carried.

subsection.content: The life-saving appliances regulations and the fire-fighting appliances regulations shall include such requirements as appear to the Secretary to be necessary to implement the provisions of the Convention and the Simla Rules 1931 or any replacement of those Rules relating to the matters referred to in subsection (1). (Amended L.N. 106 of 2002; L.N. 130 of 2007; 10 of 2009 s. 38)

subsection.leadIn: This section applies to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: ships registered in Hong Kong; and

content.leadIn: other ships while they are within the waters of Hong Kong:

subsection.proviso: Provided that this section shall not apply to a ship by reason of its being within the waters of Hong Kong if it would not have been in such waters but for stress of weather or other circumstance which neither the master nor the owner of the ship could have prevented or forestalled.

section.name: s100
section.heading: Regulations in respect of distress signals and navigational warnings

subsection.leadIn: The Secretary may make regulations prescribing— (Amended 56 of 1990 s. 10; 20 of 1996 s. 9; L.N. 106 of 2002; L.N. 130 of 2007; 10 of 2009 s. 38)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: what signals shall be used by ships as signals of distress;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the circumstances in which, and the purposes for which, any such signal is to be used and the circumstances in which it is to be revoked; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the circumstances and manner in which warnings of navigational dangers shall be reported.

subsection.content: Regulations made under this section may be made to apply to all ships registered in Hong Kong wherever they may be. (Added 56 of 1990 s. 10)

subsection.def: In this section ship (船、船舶) includes a junk and a trawler to which Part XII of the Merchant Shipping Ordinance (Cap. 281) applies. (Added 56 of 1990 s. 10)

section.name: s101
section.heading: Regulations in respect of carriage of dangerous goods

subsection.content: The Secretary may make regulations for regulating in the interests of safety the carriage of dangerous goods in ships to which this section applies. (Amended 20 of 1996 s. 9; L.N. 106 of 2002; L.N. 130 of 2007; 10 of 2009 s. 38)

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.leadIn: Regulations made under subsection (1) may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: provide that—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the contravention of any provision thereof shall be an offence; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the owner, master or such other person as the regulations shall specify shall be guilty of the offence; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: prescribe for such offence a penalty of a fine not exceeding level 4 or imprisonment for 2 years or both such fine and such imprisonment. (Added 56 of 1990 s. 11. Amended E.R. 5 of 2021)

subsection.leadIn: If any of the regulations made under subsection (1) are not complied with—

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the ship shall be deemed for the purposes of section 67 to be unsafe by reason of improper loading.

subsection.leadIn: This section applies to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: ships registered in Hong Kong; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: other ships while they are within the waters of Hong Kong.

subsection.leadIn: The Secretary may make regulations— (Amended 20 of 1996 s. 9; L.N. 106 of 2002; L.N. 130 of 2007; 10 of 2009 s. 38)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for the surveying and periodic inspection of ships to which Part IV applies;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for determining freeboards to be assigned from time to time to such ships;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: for ascertaining the length of a ship for the purposes of Part IV;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: for determining, in relation to any such ship, the deck which is to be taken to be the freeboard deck of the ship, and for requiring the position of that deck to be indicated on each side of the ship by a mark of description prescribed by the regulations;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: for determining, by reference to that mark and the freeboard for the time being assigned to any such ship, the positions in which each side of the ship is to be marked with lines of a description prescribed by the regulations, indicating the various maximum depths to which the ship may be loaded in circumstances prescribed by the regulations;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: specifying such requirements in respect of the hulls, superstructures, fittings and appliances of ships to which Part IV applies as appear to the Secretary to be relevant to the assignment of freeboards to such ships; (Amended 20 of 1996 s. 9; L.N. 106 of 2002; L.N. 130 of 2007; 10 of 2009 s. 38)

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: providing that, at the time when freeboards are assigned to a ship in accordance with these regulations, such particulars relating to those requirements as may be determined in accordance with the regulations are to be recorded in such manner as may be so determined;

paragraph.name: h
i
paragraph.content: requiring such information relating to the stability of any ship to which freeboards are assigned under the regulations, and such information relating to the loading and ballasting of any such ship, as may be determined in accordance with the regulations, to be provided for the guidance of the master of the ship in such manner as may be so determined;

paragraph.name: j
paragraph.content: for securing that certificates which are issued as International Load Line Certificates in respect of ships to which section 57 applies, and are so issued by governments, other than the Government of Hong Kong, shall be recognized for the purposes of Part IV in such circumstances as may be prescribed; (Amended 6 of 2000 s. 18)

paragraph.name: k
paragraph.content: for securing that exemption certificates which, in accordance with the Convention of 1966, are issued in respect of ships to which section 57 applies, and are so issued by governments other than the Government of Hong Kong, shall in such circumstances as may be prescribed by the regulations have the like effect for the purposes of Part IV as if they were valid Convention certificates;

paragraph.name: l
m
paragraph.content: enabling a certificate under section 51, an exemption under section 62 or a certificate under section 63 to be extended within such limits and in such circumstances as may be prescribed by the regulations;

paragraph.name: n
paragraph.content: providing for the endorsement, termination or cancellation of a certificate under section 51, an exemption under section 62 or a certificate under section 63.

subsection.leadIn: In relation to any matter authorized or required by Part IV to be prescribed by the load line regulations, those regulations may make different provision by reference to, or to any combination of, any of the following—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: different descriptions of ships;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: different areas;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: different seasons of the year; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: any other different circumstances.

section.name: s103
section.heading: Regulations for testing anchor and chain cables

subsection.leadIn: The Secretary may make regulations with respect to the testing of anchors and chain cables for use in ships registered in Hong Kong, and such regulations may in particular— (Amended 20 of 1996 s. 9; L.N. 106 of 2002; L.N. 130 of 2007; 10 of 2009 s. 38)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: prescribe the manner in which tests of anchors and cables are to be carried out, the tensile strains and breaking strains to be employed in such tests and the requirements to be fulfilled by equipment used for the purposes of such tests;

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.content: provide for the supervision of such tests and marking, and for the inspection of such equipment, by a Government surveyor appointed under section 5;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: provide that the regulations shall not apply to anchors or cables of such classes or descriptions as may be specified in the regulations or which are exempted therefrom by the Director in accordance with any power in that behalf contained in the regulations.

subsection.def: In this section anchor (錨) and chain cable (錨鏈) include any shackle attached to or intended to be used in connexion with the anchor or cable.

section.name: s104
section.heading: Regulations relating to carriage of grain
section.text: The Secretary may make regulations prescribing, in relation to the loading of ships generally or of ships of any class, any precautions which are necessary or reasonable precautions to prevent grain from shifting.

subsection.content: The Secretary may make regulations prescribing requirements to be complied with where cargo is carried in any uncovered space on the deck of a ship to which Part IV applies; and different requirements may be so prescribed in relation to different descriptions of ships, different descriptions of cargo, different voyages or classes of voyage, different seasons of the year or any other different circumstances. (Amended 20 of 1996 s. 9; L.N. 106 of 2002; L.N. 130 of 2007; 10 of 2009 s. 38)

If the load line regulations provide, either generally or in particular cases or classes of cases, for assigning special freeboards to ships which are to have effect only where a cargo of timber is carried, then, without prejudice to the generality of subsection (1), the deck cargo regulations may prescribe special requirements to be complied with in circumstances where any such special freeboard has effect.

In prescribing any such special requirements as are mentioned in subsection (2), the Secretary shall have regard in particular to Chapter IV of the Convention of 1966. (Amended 20 of 1996 s. 9; L.N. 106 of 2002; L.N. 130 of 2007; 10 of 2009 s. 38)

subsection.leadIn: If the deck cargo regulations are contravened—

paragraph.name: a
